segments.en: Linked Discourses 35
7. With Migajāla
63. With Migajāla (1st)
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā migajālo yena bhagavā … pe …
segments.en: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha …

segments.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā migajālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: and said to him:
“Sir, they speak of one who lives alone.

segments.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, ekavihārī hoti, kittāvatā ca pana sadutiyavihārī hotī”ti?
segments.en: How is one who lives alone defined? And how is living with a partner defined?”

segments.pli: “Santi kho, migajāla, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: “Migajāla, there are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

segments.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
segments.en: this gives rise to relishing.
When there’s relishing there’s lust.
When there’s lust there is a fetter.

segments.pli: Nandisaṃyojanasaṃyutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu sadutiyavihārīti vuccati.
segments.en: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live with a partner.
There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

segments.pli: Santi kho, migajāla, jivhāviññeyyā rasā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

segments.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
segments.en: this gives rise to relishing.
When there’s relishing there’s lust.
When there’s lust there is a fetter.

segments.pli: Nandisaṃyojanasaṃyutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu sadutiyavihārīti vuccati.
segments.en: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live with a partner.

segments.pli: Evaṃvihārī ca, migajāla, bhikkhu kiñcāpi araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni;
segments.en: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live with a partner, even if they frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.
Why is that?
For craving is their partner, and they haven’t given it up.
That’s why they’re said to live with a partner.

segments.pli: Santi ca kho, migajāla, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

segments.pli: Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato nandī nirujjhati.
segments.en: relishing ceases.
When there’s no relishing there’s no lust.
When there’s no lust there’s no fetter.

segments.pli: Nandisaṃyojanavisaṃyutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu ekavihārīti vuccati … pe …
segments.en: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.

segments.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, jivhāviññeyyā rasā … pe …
segments.en: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

segments.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
segments.en: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

segments.pli: Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato nandī nirujjhati.
segments.en: relishing ceases.
When there’s no relishing there’s no lust.
When there’s no lust there’s no fetter.

segments.pli: Nandisaṃyojanavippayutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu ekavihārīti vuccati.
segments.en: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.

segments.pli: Evaṃvihārī ca, migajāla, bhikkhu kiñcāpi gāmante viharati ākiṇṇo bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi rājūhi rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.
segments.en: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live alone, even if they live in the neighborhood of a village crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples.
Why is that?
For craving is their partner, and they have given it up.
That’s why they’re said to live alone.”

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Migajāla asks how one lives alone, and how with a partner. The Buddha says that so long as one is bound by desire to the senses, one lives with a partner. A mendicant free of such desire dwells alone, even if they live in close association with worldly people.
